aicpa-topic.title: Chapter 3 — Regulatory Considerations

body.p:
Regulatory Considerations
Guidance in this chapter should not replace a full understanding of the rules and interpretations issued by all applicable regulatory agencies. Also see paragraph 1.149 of this guide, which discusses the evolving regulatory landscape for digital assets.
3.01 Pursuant to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (the 1934 Act), the SEC developed a comprehensive system to regulate broker-dealers and the securities industry in general.

3.02 The audit and reporting requirements for securities broker-dealers are regulated by SEC Rule 17a-5 under the 1934 Act. Such requirements for broker-dealers that are also commodities brokers, known as CFTC-registered futures commission merchants (FCMs) or CFTC-registered introducing brokers (IBs) are regulated by Regulations 1.10 and 1.16 of the Commodity Exchange Act, whereas the requirements for registered broker-dealers in U.S. government securities are regulated by Section 405.2 of the regulations pursuant to Section 15C of the 1934 Act. Those rules are listed in the “Commodities Brokers” section of this chapter.
3.03 The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (Dodd-Frank Act), signed into law on July 21, 2010, called for a number of regulatory changes related to the securities industry.

3.04 One of the provisions of this act amended the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 (SOX) to give the PCAOB full oversight authority over audits of broker-dealers registered with the SEC, including nonissuer broker-dealers.
As discussed in the preface to this guide, AICPA issued Technical Question & Answer section 7100.16, which is specific to brokers, dealers, and futures commission merchants. It states that both issuer and nonissuer broker-dealers registered with the SEC are considered public business entities (PBEs). Therefore, both issuer and nonissuer broker-dealers registered with the SEC would follow effective dates for PBEs when implementing new pronouncements.
The Dodd-Frank Act included a provision that audits of broker-dealers registered with the SEC, including nonissuer broker-dealers, be performed in accordance with PCAOB auditing standards. The SEC finalized amendments to SEC Rule 17a-5, through Release No. 34-70073, Broker-Dealer Reports, on July 30, 2013, which require PCAOB auditing and attestation standards be applied to the annual reporting for broker-dealers registered with the SEC effective for fiscal year-ends on or after June 1, 2014.
For further information, see Frequently Asked Questions Concerning the Amendments to Certain Broker-Dealer Financial Responsibility Rules, and Frequently Asked Questions Concerning the July 30, 2013 Amendments to the Broker-Dealer Financial Reporting Rule. Both are available on the SEC staff’s “List of Frequently Asked Questions” at https://www.sec.gov/divisions/marketreg/mrfaq.
Before undertaking the audit of a broker-dealer in securities, the auditor obtains an understanding of regulatory factors. This generally includes reading the applicable standards and rules to have an understanding of the prescribed scope of the audit and the related reporting requirements.
